txt: Ambition is absent
The echo chamber is deafening
Accountability, management and vision sorely lacking
Salaries (specialy from the UNs) really need to be reduced
Abolish UN agency logos--One UN, one logo, no competition
A rising tide lifts all boats.
Professional humanitarian community does not have to feel corporate.
We act too slow: for programs, for internal processes, and for transformational change.
Qualitative data must to be used more, as quantitative metrics often oversimplify nuanced viewpoints for HQ and donors far from the field.
Creativity requires space and time. The humanitarian sector must change, but without exepcting concurrent transformation and implementation.
The current system can't reform itself - voices from outside and ground must be prioritised
Rushing reform because of funding shortages will make things worse
The humanitarian principle of “neutrality” is a problem
Cash-based aid is not being used enough
Local aid agencies should get much more international funding
Not everything can be localised, we need to retain some international crisis response capabilities
Localised aid is not always community led aid
Humanitarian principles need to be reframed rather than refuted, so they retain their power but regain their relevance.
I’d always thought of the principles as indivisible. At the macro level neutrality is withering. But perhaps within contexts it is relevant
The reset of a compromised system that has defied reform canny rely on tools and approaches from within system to drive future reform!
Humanitarian principles defined by crisis affected communities - those are important
We need to get back to basics on international solidarity- people to people - strip out institutions and orgs we cant afford. Tech can help
Reform is direly needed, but there’s a risk the same system is recreated without challenging the status quo and shifting the locus of power
Humanitarian principles need be refined as they don't fit the reality nor the purpose
The UN cannot by its nature be neutral as it is a org made up of member states. But the principle of neutrality remains important
The system cannot reform itself and the reset needs to include perspectives from communities, including radical voices.
There needs to be recognition that humanitarian principles are incompatible with donors unless the money is totally unrestricted
The humanitarian system is patriarchal and colonial. Therefore feminist and decolonial perspectives are needed for true reform.
The Fundamental Principles are still paramount; but recognize our interconnectedness and our effect on the climate and biodiversity.
Our restricted, institutional funding model is in direct opposition with localization and accountability to affected populations.
Advocacy should focus on affected populations not on funding.
Positive humanitarian outcomes should not be centered in survival, they should be centered in vitality.
Every response should begin by asking what the affected community needs rather than bringing a prescribed solution to get buy-in.
Competing with other organizations for funding has negatively impacted humanitarian service delivery.
Governments and governmental funding should not occupy the same humanitarian space to maintain independence and distinction.
Local actors not supported properly to scale their work
Requiring branded aid delivery goes against the principle of neutrality.
Emergency assistance methods should never increase risk to future emergencies.
Sustainability is no longer enough, and regenerative action is now required to take additive steps rather than only maintain the status quo.
For transformative change to take place true collaboration within and outside the sector is an imperative.
Emergency preparedness and disaster risk reduction programming require vast investment (proactive) over emergency response (reactive).
Humanitarian diplomatic representation is imperative for aid worker security and for aid to reach affected populations.
Context-specific project planning is essential to meet humanitarian needs as they exist in a specific location and for a specific population
The humanitarian sector still too closely identifies with saviorism.
Conflict-sensitive programming is no longer enough, programming needs to actively strengthen positive peace.
People/Institutions from the Global North should get out of the way of local organisations, their role should be fundraising and support.
Funders cannot be allowed to influence how money is spent locally, as they don't share the same incentives & needs as affected populations.
The perception of widespread corruption is the biggest barrier to direct financial support for local communities and stakeholders
Aid providers must be more transparent, incl. finances, and give people the information they need to meaningfully engage in discussions.
Any reform needs to move away from the cluster system if it wants to be community-led.
It is unethical for INGOs/UN to maintain such large numbers of staff, when local organisations struggle to get funding for the bare minimum.
Saving lives requires being efficient and saving on overhead. Review the need for support from regional offices, special assistants etc.
Fewer international actors competing for same funding to deliver similar services, requiring merging or rationalization of agencies/orgs.
A mindset of international actors to transfer power, rather than shift power, to local actors. Think, work yourself out of a job.
Less top-heavy international aid system with fewer staff (incl. number of staff and director levels), and less bureaucracy.
Humanitarian assistance should stop after 6-8 months. If needs persist after, it is a political/economic issue, without aid solutions.
The level of salaries and allowances in senior UN grades is morally corrupt and needs reforming.
Area-Based Coordination and a corresponding funding model can allow funds to be spent more effectively, in line with community preferences
OCHA is supposed to coordinate, not implement. Back to basics.
Humanitarian aid should be in support of development (to the extent possible led by local governments and organisations), not the main goal
Slimmed down system purely humanitarian focused  - funding-reliant on solidarity of general population - away from politicly driven states
Donors push everyone to be more efficient but they are the one duplicating funding to initiatives and projects doing the same things.
These statements are binary and inadequate
Blindly promoting 'Localisation' risks silencing some local actors at the expense of other. Nuance is needed in defining approaches.
The triple nexus of humanitarian/development/peacebuilding may look good on paper but is virtually impossible to implement in the real world
"neutrality" is not about closing our eyes, pretending all sides are the same or staying silent in front of war crimes. It should be aware.
The existing aid system does a good job of saving lives and alleviating suffering. Whilst reform is needed now is not the time.
Knee-jerk reform triggered by current instabilities won't help. We need a clear future state in mind based on solid foresight work
Humanitarian space will shrink as agencies refuse to stand up to Governments for fear of losing money. We need a coalition of radical ideas
DRR programming should not be limited to preparedness (at the expenses of prevention and mitigation)
Back to basics. Humanitarians should not be bureaucrats; rather, they should be people deeply committed to principles and humanity first.
Coordination mechanisms (e.g. clusters) should ensure that community engagement (sensitive, inclusive) are essential part of their mandate.
International actors to embrace solidarity rather than personal power.
Those who managed the system so far with problematic stances (e.g. aid can be soft power) are unfit to reform: they would make things worse
Humanitarian aid should be better at leveraging strengths of communities (capacity of responders, coordination local initiatives)
Competition mindset, visibility, organization survival first has corrupted humanitarianism
Forget obsessive measurement at the output level. Look for a meaningful understanding of complex context and responses.
We need to be careful that localisation does not mean making everything contextual and relative. We need underlying principles and standards
We’ve known for decades that aid is broken, has not achieved its goals it must be radically simplified and triaged, driven by global South
The idea of localised response and the theory behind localisation is great - but do we truly understand what it means in practice.
We must focus more on the ultimate objectives, not just repeating the immediate response. Be creative, and aim for long-term shifts.
we need to think much less about 'an emergency aid system'! Think more about how to help people get the support they need.
The bulk of funding allocated through pool-based funds with representative decision making from within countries.
the aid system is too big, cluttered with organisations whose main skill is marketing. let 70% of the aid system - NGOs, UN, go to the wall
Create a fund to defend civil society actors who are arrested or attacked by the state.
Area-based (geographical) coordination in lieu of clusters.
We need to keep humanitarian principles so we can act to reach everyone. No one expects you to 'be neutral' - your actions should be neutral
Smaller organizations, smaller grants geographicaly focused. Big organizations bieng more cost efficient is a lie.
Spend less money on sustaining large offices and experts in email humanitarianism - and scale up directly support to local actors
Humanitarians must use companies, as projects, to self-sustain their work, and pivot for long term sustainability without gov. Funding
Self selection and nepotism leads to mediocrity
Majority of funding to go to pooled funds which redispatch them to local and national actors based on collective strategy & plan of action
More joint analysis and planning across the nexus for development to really pick things up where it can/should/could
Pre-determined response at the onset as needs are often the same, tailor within 6 months or close down. External monitoring to assess.
Protection should be front and center of what we do, with key senior roles defending and upholding it
UN should rely more on local talent rather than mantaining internstional staff that oftenly are not prepared to context based problems
All major INGOs to develop an incentive based redundancy system.  Reward for transfer of key skills to local/national partners
Neutrality is not apathy, but it is instead both gritty and counter cultural.
humanitarian principles are a goal, like a quilt that covers everything, not a pre-condition, made in a wedding dress we try to keep clean
Local actors are not always best placed to support (politics, bias, discrimination), and that's ok. It's not all or nothing.
Shared open data and open source technology resources are foundational to the Humanitarian sector.
Diverse experience across organisations and contexts improves outcomes
Humanitarian coordination is de-duplication, at best. Collaboration and cooperation requires trust and systems to support it
Humanitarian work is political by definition, denying this fact is where the system goes terribly wrong
Aid and econ development, is not a monolith. These statements, like the aid sector writ large, need to be broken down and contextualized.
If you’re not part of the solution, you’re part of the problem. And vice versa.
Limit our form of action (humanitarian, largely parallel) to situations of active conflict and situations of deliberate and malign neglect.
Limit interventions to life-saving/sustaining ones, working with local capacities (if this does not limit our access to those most in need)
Get the UN out of the business of being a donor and an implementer, radically simplify the cluster system and open it up to local actors
Get the UN out of the business of being a donor and an implementer, radically simplify the cluster system (opening it to local actors)
Donors are the customers of the aid system, shaping a competitive, risk-averse, and bureaucratic environment. They must change first.
All international and local actors have adapted to meet toxic donors needs. Change incentives so communities to drive decisions.
Reduce duplication of bureaucratic and compliance constraints, reduce superstructure (consultants, TPMs, Geneva and other HO nonsense, etc.)
Aid is only as good as the quality of field staff and community participation. It's not about whether the organisation is local or not.
Aid is as good as field staff and community participation. it's not about whether the org is local. It's makng power closer to affected peop
We will never be accountable to communities unless they can 'hire' and 'fire' us
We should acknowledge the white elephant, box-ticking projects, and understand the common denominators to weed them out.
Global data on who is funding whom , for what, where. Fragmented, short-term grants is the root of many box-ticking, ineffective projects.
UN needs full reform to get rid of all the duplication. They spend too much on useless staff & merchandise, and are so removed from reality.
Aid repeats the same mistakes over and over without results. Why are we still providing food assistance to some countries for 40+ years?
The UN has become largely useless. Full of duplication and overpaid senior staff who take credit for the work of implementers.
The HRP process is a joke. They tell us to cut it down because there is not enough money - which is literally the point…
Would be useful if OCHA could consider actually coordinating something for a change instead of just presenting the same PowerPoints.
Strip out useless HQ (and regional) staff across large NGOs and UN. The money should be going to implementers and only a few key roles at HQ
Localisation is essential but let’s not be blind to issues like local biases & politics, corruption, neutrality, resources, capacity
UN needs to be less focussed on branding (and spending funds on stupid merchandise) and more focussed on supporting partners to deliver.
International aid should stop undermining the Indigenous response capacity and should rather focus on complementarity.
Excessive monetisation of international aid patterns has turned it into an industry, and volunteerism has almost disappeared.
Close down country offices. Let international actors reimagine their complementary role from the countries of their origin.
Holding host governments accountable when they are often a huge part of the problem (esp exacerbating conflicts, corruptions etc)
Don't judge an NGO/thinktank/donor on national or international, but how many people and women from the south are in position of leadership
The future of aid will be fragmented and not based on global consensus. The current 'formal' system will become leaner and meaner
Communities need to be able to 'hire' the services that they need from NGOs instead of NGOs choosing for them what they need
Precarious work contracts in both the Global North and South undermine the sustainability and effectiveness of humanitarian work
Need a far more effective and efficient UN system. Both functionally and financially.
There's many emerging ways like sclr to put grassroots community-based groups in the driving seat to design/deliver their own interventions
Addressing conflict and/or protection-related drivers of humanitarian need requires local consultation, financial and diplomatic investment
To be effective, humanitarian aid needs to be based on gender and inclusion analysis and adapted to meet the needs of the most marginalised
socially marginalised people and those most at risk need to inform decision making and have their priorities and their capacities recognised
Women’s and Feminist Funds are important donors in the humanitarian space but their contributions need greater recognition.
Far too much of available donor funds go to big UN orgs far from progressive on people-centred locally-led work - prioritise actors who are
Don't expect a one-size-fits-all reform to work. The humanitarian system is composed of many complementary parts; each needs its own cure.
Clusters have outlived their use, but a system with no coordination functions breeds chaos. Ensure strong, shared & inclusive leadership
Reform humanitarian principles for the new world we live in. Neutrality and impartiality in particular need a rethink. Think Gaza, Ukraine
In active conflict settings, much more attention needed for psychosocial trauma-related support for both people in need and responders.
Humanitarian aid is last - not first - resort: ‘prevention always, development wherever possible, humanitarian action when necessary'.
Humanitarian aid is often used in places where strengthening pro-poor social protection schemes would make more sense.
The cluster system has created a layer and complexity to delivery that excludes, wastes money and is unaccountable.
localisation is radical, but necessary for humanitarian reforms. 80% of conceptualization and decisionmaking should happen locally.
Humanitarians as providers of last resort where STRENGTHENED government social protection and DRM systems have been overwhelmed
Localisation is also about local STATE actors (e.g. frontline workers) & their capacities and roles in preparedness and anticipatory action
Humanitarians unable to say if they supported the same people over time/across actors -only linking to STATE systems will help be systematic
Incentives wrong: we should not be measuring #people reached but national systems strengthened to ensure future preparedness, mitigation etc
The financial crisis is an opportunity to reshape the humanitarian system which became inefficient, bureaucratic and supply driven
We need to rethink how 'in need' is defined based on community experiences and inputs not top-down western centric definitions
The UN system needs disruptive restructuring: Merge FAO, ILO, WFP etc., & create 1 UN body that can effectively support multiple priorities
Cutting across the so called local and international divide, national staff need to be more represented at decision tables.
Aid worker safety and security needs to be taken more seriously. Aid workers are dying in record numbers. Nothing changes.
More emphasis on supporting local governments to deliver. In places plagued by decades of famine &conflict we see govt unable to do the work
Get rid of UN duplication of agencies. They don’t even have a single HR system. No wonder they can’t  coordinate a humanitarian response.
A UN that focusses less on giving out blue t-shirts and for every international day, and just focusses on channeling money through partners
UN are not “a partner in development”. They’re a bureaucratic, inefficient waste of money. They should be removed as middlemen in responses
Religious NGOs need to stop proselytising to vulnerable people. Just do the work, cut the nonsense.
Clusters have become so bureaucratic drawing people away from response delivery to spend half the week completing 5Ws & attending meetings
More focus on aid worker well being - health, mental/psychological support, education opportunities, safety & security etc
NGOs & UN should provide similar funding to single staff in lieu of all the benefits parents get for kids (educational, travel, healthcare)
Aid worker background checks need to change. Police checks from home country is useless if they’ve been living abroad. Offenders move around
A UN with a single P11 and streamlined HR system. It’s currently representative of how siloed the UN is.
Hold host governments accountable for man-made humanitarian situations.
The system focuses too much on 'people reached' which is backward looking, rather than remaining gaps, i.e. people we still need to help
The UN should stand back and provide technical advice, generate evidence and advocacy only
International aid actors need to find ways to support mutual aid initiatives without crushing them
Humanitarian response could work as an ecosystem of many different forms of charity and solidarity. Not a single UN led system of response
Community engagement - done safely and inclusively - is vital in informing our reforms
We must listen to affected populations more, and offer baskets of solutions, including cash
Global north should provide cash and technical expertise only, not opinions
Local decision about resource allocation
Local aid agencies should get much more national / own state funding
It’s unreasonable to suggest western donors hand over cash to countries plagued by conflict and corruption, and then not have an opinion
Many countries receiving western donor $ actually have resources but mismanage them. A lot of funding is being thrown into a bottomless pit
Local voices need to feature more prominently in responses. But there needs a balance with foreign expertise when not available locally
The UN needs a HUGE shake up to get rid of the dead weight it’s been propping up and sucking extraordinary amounts of aid money
Deal with aid sector corruption. So much money stolen and no way to hold people accountable for theft of funds (esp. expats who just flee)
Peel the layers of the onion and get rid of the useless bureaucracy which slows down a response (looking at you UN and your HRPs etc)
UN/NGOs could lose their celeb ambassadors and save a lot of donor money. No more narcissistic poverty porn (Megan Markle, Ed Sheeran etc)
Can we all agree to ban branded  fishing vests when we reform the UN system? No humanitarian needs that many pockets.
Are voices from countries that receive emergency aid, with lived experience of living in conflict and disaster zones being consulted on this
Is mental healthcare prioritised, culturally sensitive and available in local languages?
What can be learnt from other sectors? Valuing lived experience, 'co-production' etc.
Why should people in their own country be required to speak English if not an official language?
Let's stop talking about goung to the field?
Are the voices of people living in areas affected by conflict and disaster being amplified here?
Truly multidimensional, nuanced representations of people living in areas affected by conflict or disaster or hearing from them directly
Using acronyms like IDPs can dehumanise people
Multilingualism needs to be valued more, including speaking local languages
Locally led with international solidarity where needed
An MSc in Dev't Studies does not qualify someone to provide humanitarian aid in a developed country; why should it in a developing country?
Donors feel entitled to unreasonable levels of detailed metrics, reporting, information sharing, gets in the way of getting the work done.
We need to be clearer about what problems are ameniable to 'humanitarian solutions' and which are not especially re protection and poverty.
Key cluster system's failure - overwhelming reporting burden - is driven by donors - their expectations need to be reset.
Too many new 'initiatives' dreampt up by HQ and donors - sucking up staff time and delivering nothing - Agenda for Protection???
HQ staff especially UN must serve in the field first, in real crisises and be regularly rotated out of Geneva and NY.
Key protection functions standardised and merged into singular system - PSEA, AAP - one actor, close to the community for the whole response
Self-awareness & an open acknowledgement of the self-serving dynamics of humanitarian aid would contribute to honest and informed solutions
Our first mission should be to 'Restore Hope' to the most vulnerable. Here is an example https://www.lsngroup.org/post/hope-what-s-in-a-word
Our objective should be to restore 'hope' to the most vulnerable and in greatest need
Aid workers (esp locals) are dying because safety & security isn’t prioritised. Needs very careful consideration in localisation strategies
Aid organisations need to stop poaching CBO & govt workers to work for them. Aim should be to strengthen existing systems not dismantle them
A fully reformed UN getting rid of duplicate agencies and mandates. Remove deadweight duplicate roles and ridiculous branding requirements.
UN needs to decide if it’s coordinating or delivering or a proxy-donor. They try to do it all now and it’s not working.
Fully resourced and capacitated local agencies. More focus on strengthening orgs like local Red Cross who have huge reach and ready to go
A humanitarian system that complements and strengthens local orgs and systems and doesn’t duplicate them to die when they go
Less competition between UN agencies and between NGOs. It needs teamwork to get things done not the biggest taking over and duplicating work
Less over-processed data and reporting requirements from UN and donors, to let the implementers get on with it.
MDGs and SDGs are never achieved. Ever! Be realistic and also have local governments working with us to achieve them
Consolidate the thousands of UN guidances, standards, processes, HRPs, HNO, cluster plans. Stop Wasting time for docs that arent read /used.
No more celebrity ambassadors
75% of funding to local actors where they then vet and select international actors to partner with for program design, implementation, etc.
A criminal and sex offender registry system. They continue to move from post to post in the sector with impunity. SEA is a huge issue
The UN needs to take a back seat. It was never meant to be delivering aid.
The UN and donors should even just pretend that they care about accountability. Release all of your data. Who gets aid and why?
The humanitarian sector needs not be be global or local, but plural. With open deliberation and decision making spaces
Impact evidence should drive humanitarian policy
Humanitarian action should be risk based, not just needs based. Get ahead of the disasters we can predict.
Improving organisational efficiency by investing in people, products and services that gives best value for the money must be top priority.
Best humanitarian system is simple, professional and sensitive enough to meet needs of the community it serves.
Listen to what is wanted and needed rather than impose inappropriate ideas that just don’t fit/work, driven by the humanitarian ‘business.’
UN System with significant reduction in ASG, D2 and D1 roles.
Significant reductions in UN footprint. Consolidated offices and roles where duplication exists. Revision of agency mandates
UN/donors: resources, area based coord. Aid workers: research, advocacy, solidarity. Locals: aid and development delivery
Humanitarian work is a connected ecosystem. Local and international actors are not opposite concepts. Remove silos.
context matters and should inform how the most vulnerable people are protected and receive support. No to cookie cutter categories of aid.
Traditional donorship creates inevitable power relations. A humanitarian tax on global wealth would ensure a fairer coverage of needs.
UN agencies have wrong incentives. they are like oligarchs and must be dismantled
A clear articulation of its limited but essential mandate
Class divide between UN, Red Cross, ‘big’ iNGO staff and ‘the rest’ is an impediment to effective humanitarian action
Humanitarian response is self serving, crowding out other nat and int'l actors which could have actually prevented or pre-empted the crisis
Protection of Civilians is in crisis. Why? Drone warfare, vanishing humanitarian space, and increasingly blurry use of protection concept
agree in principle, but local actors are not a silver bullet, particularly in conflict situations How support/facilitate, ensure quality ?
UN has a role to facilitate, negotiate access etc (think backstop role of WHO rather than 'implementation' of UNICEF)
varies - HRP can be a wishlist, and is always over inflated, but a exercise such as this can have value if done well
define solidarity : there is a monitoring role needed by someone for quality assurance, neutrality, non partisanship etc
agree - but again, access, political reach important. And 'protection' can mean many things - needs clarification
Accountability is key, and currently does not exist in the system. System is about self congratulation and hiding uncomfortable findings
the system in an oligarchy of UN aid capture (too few underperforming Un agencies get lions share of funds, and use them inefficiently )
metrics used for success are poor (eg people reached) opaque and meaningless. relevance, speed, quality of assistance needs capturing
'localisation' as a term needs substantial unpacking and clarifying : we are often talking about different things
Consolidate a multisectoral humanitarian capacity into one UN agency to drive efficiency, overcome silos and enhance local engagement.
Start-ups succeed by providing a solution to client's "pain-points". Do we understand the pain-points of beneficiaries in accessing aid?
UN removed as a middleman. UNICEF, you are not a “development partner”, you are a middleman. Back in your box please
Results need to be less focussed on # pple reached. Reaching an entire nation through a 5 minute radio segment does not equal impact.
Less competition amongst NGOs. Complaining about UN duplication when you all have seperate offices, warehouses, logistics in small towns.
UN needs to be less territorial. Taking credit for the work of NGOs by forcing their logo on everything just serves to heighten resentment
Donors more engaged with field realities and needs before imposing unrealistic project themes and designs
Less waste of resources on junk like t-shirts and hats for every international day and spend that money on projects.
Lrg NGOs remove barriers to work in HQ. They’re happy to sponsor visas to work in warzones but not for HQ roles, despite singing “diversity”
The UN cluster system fully revamped. It could be very useful if run properly but has become a time wasting, inefficient bureaucracy.
UN to cut out all those useless NY, Rome, Geneva roles so those funds can be spent closer to the response
A world where MSF decides to actually coordinate with others (and their staff wash those dirty white t-shirts)
Removing the competition out of responses. We are there to serve the people, not have the most $, biggest offices or most prolific logo
Some clear advocacy on the when earmarked grants vs flexible funding is appropriate and impactful, and when it is not.
Projects would systematically check: is this what people want? is anyone else doing something similar?
Project calls and proposals would be evidence-based and drafted with local stakeholders (not by people sitting in HQs copy pasting text)
All humanitarian projects not taking place in protracted crises include an exit strategy, drafted in collaboration with development orgs.
No more waste-of-time projects to "support governments" or "assess national systems" signed without target-country approval.
Humanitarians in hardship duty stations (especially local staff) have systematic access to mental health professionals specialised in trauma
International orgs and experts can bring new solutions to old problems-- foresight methods, use of A.I to predict weather hazards
A safe forum for dissecting failed projects and their causes, NOT to assign blame but to do better next time.
Field implementers enabled by supporting staff: comms, HR, IT, wellbeing, finance, admin, and management. Core functions = stable contracts.
Funding allocated = needs understood + appropriate solution suggested + evidence you can do it  and no one else is already doing it/
Get rid of bloated UN salaries and middle management
Make “training” and “capacity building” for local partners contextually relevant and practical.
Greater focus on aid worker safety and mental health support.
Support for whistleblowers
A UN and NGO system that takes SEA seriously instead of brushing it under the rug. Offenders continue to get promoted and moved around
Stop using “innovation” to continue reinventing the wheel to make it less practical. Sometimes local solutions work better
A system that has the balls to speak out on atrocities in a Francesca Albanese kinda way. Not tinkering around the edges and being silent
A system that doesn’t continue rewarding oppressive regimes like Afghanistan where women have zero rights, but we still provide “aid”
Support female aid workers with (or to have) families. So many drop out of the sector age 30-50 because they get no support.
Basic things like having body armour which accommodates breasts (and doesn’t assume we all have male bodies).
HEAT training that has actively thought through how to talk about prevention and support for aid workers facing sexual violence / rape
National disaster management frameworks should be strengthened through better ownership of decision-critical information
Donor governments need to get tough with host countries and use ODA as leverage to hold them to account. Tell populations who is to blame.
Local or international is a false dichotomy. If the funds are from western tax payers it will never be a locally led system
Donors should fund ngos with hq and staff from their own countries, it is part of their soft power abroad.
It does not matter if international or local actors deliver the aid, but that affected people get support and aid diversion is kept low
Corruption, bias and prejudice will increase with more local actors, who are often not representative of affected populations either
Multi donor pooled funds should be used at country level to distribute the majority of the aid based on what actors are best placed
The current humanitarian system has avoided major reform efforts to date as it generally works quite well in many challenging contexts.
The red cross model of local branches, national societies and an international network is ideal. This is the model to expand and replicate.
Humanitarian reform is navel gazing. The ecosystem will continue to evolve as it always have, it is already responsive to change.
Programe managers need support that tailors global learning to real-time needs, not lengthy reports that are hard to access or apply
To de-bureaucratise aid, we must rethink risk, allow for failure, and rebuild trust with leaner, more adaptive systems and processes.
Expecting donors not to have a say in how aid is spent is unreasonable. If you want that model then let host countries fund own responses
Host governments are to blame for circumstances in their country. If they don’t want interference then they should fund their own responses
NGO and UN HQ staff should have worked in the field for a minimum of 5 yrs to at least be remotely useful and grounded in reality
We need to cut the bureaucratic red tape that slows down responses. Less time wasting reporting and matrix’s that no-one reads.
Despite proximity to a response & local knowledge strengths, Increasing use of local actors will likely increase both biases and corruption.
OCHA could start by actually coordinating responses. That would be helpful.
Aid worker safety should be a fundamental priority
Less nonsense “coordination” meeting groups. There are too many layers or meetings with almost all the same people and agendas
A proper aid workers union in place
Local talent pools should be in place to access the best people in-country
Don’t poach govt staff then complain things aren’t working in a country.
Support female humanitarians to work and have a family. They all disappear at 30 because the system fails to support them
Aid diversion and corruption from host governments is properly addressed (Ethiopia and Somalia are excellent examples of what not to do)
A proper think about both benefits and risks of digital data of beneficiaries. Any data portal can ultimately be breached.
Think through how implementers can share resources rather than compete and duplicate work.
Less fishing vests
Greater clarity on the role of the UN. Feels like sometimes even they don’t know
We should build on past successes and learn from mistakes, rather than continuously reinventing the wheel, at considerable expense
Less documents. No-one reads them and it takes us away from our core work of implementing
Aid workers undergo basic psychological testing before going to hard duty stations. Too often unstable colleagues become a risk & burden
Realistic logframes would be nice for a change
Wealthy middle eastern and Asian countries stepping up as donors would be a positive change
International NGOs which don’t provide basics like security measures and insurance for their staff should be named and shamed
Better salaries. We often put our lives on the line for miniscule amounts of money, whilst HQ staff in cushy offices are paid more.
UN has 1 IT system. Filling out a 4hr application for every UN job because the templates per agency are different, is absolutely ludicrous.
Raise our salaries. We put our life on the line and sacrifice a lot of things in life, yet are paid like interns.
To much emphasis is placed on aid being a neo-colonial system. Reform needs non-traditional donor countries to stand up and offer aid
All countries should contribute 0.7% of GDP not matter their wealth into a global pot. The worst-off countries then get allocated the funds
Middle East and wealthier Asian nations contribute as donors
Countries which claim to be exporting basic food commodities (rice, wheat etc) should not receive food assistance
We work towards helping developing countries to manage budgets and economies instead of continuing to fund corrupt regimes
Greater focus on self sufficiency and exit strategies. Funding same communities for 50yrs without results demonstrates things not working
Countries which continually pillage aid funding (ie Ethiopia aid diversion) shouldnt continue to receive aid if not reaching beneficiaries
Aid workers receive pensions like the way military do. We finish a contract and are left with nothing having sacrificed everything
Basic min. standards for INGOs around staff benefits, medical, insurance, evacuations, safety & security. No commitment to staff, no funding
Walk the talk. How can we be for women’s rights and still go along with just sending male staff to afghanistan
Remove all the nexus and buzzword nonsense. We spend more time updating guidance to include new words that mean nothing
Donors like USA need to stop being self righteous, giving advice on HR abuses when they have long histories of human rights abuses
Donor countries own governments are complicit in fueling and selling arms to the very conflicts we are responding to. This needs to stop
Exit strategies needed. Aid should be for the most vulnerable, not a long term bandaid covering government mismanagement and neglect
Localise coordination. There are too many forums & mechanisms that overlap. Most run by foreigners. At the end of the day locals should lead
Remember there is a human cost to reforming and/or rebuilding the aid sector. There will be real consequences for jobs. Plan in advance.
Nurture local efficiencies, coordination and adaptation. Not everything needs to be top-down led. Red Cross in a lot of countries works well
Remove the pretentious red tape and over engineering of coordination. We overthink coordination, wasting time doing it. Back to basics
What constitutes a good statement depends on the context
Affected by a disaster? Would you not just want access to quick State led compensation and information on where and how to access it?
Why do much emphasis on community led actors? Is it not just another middleman between the affected individual and the Gov. duty bearer
Good intentions or a blind love for "radical disruption" alone do not help delivering aid, food, water, for millions in need!
Nothing wrong with fundamental principles (humanity, neutrality, impartiality, independence), but plenty improvements in ways of delivering.
Less fluff, more impact!
The global humanitarian class has become too donor-serving, removed from reality and actively silencing of internal dissent and speaking out
We need less silos but more systems thinking in humanitarian action (e.g. integrated programs, digital identity)
A good statement has a clear emotional connection to its intended audience.
Somewhere in the system someone has to hold everyone (international, national, local) accountable
There needs to be a role somewhere for quality assurance - not just quantity but quality of response. Could this be OCHA's new role?
Let's stop planning and measuring quantity (of people reached, stuff delivered) and instead plan and measure for quality and impact.
Coordination can be strategic, normative, or operational.  We do lots of operational but very little normative or strategic. Time to shift.
Localisation = effective funding to local actors, effective partner to local actors, and real local leadership of response. Not just fund %
The real problem is that taxpayers - who pay for aid - don't believe in aid anymore. Need to show them why, results and value for money
We need to work out + mitigate the impact of much less devt funds on hum action - no roadbuilding, no governance, security sector reform etc
Governments in crisis countries should either fund, co-fund or be presented with a bill for hum aid in their own countries.
Bigger car parks with electric charging at UN headquarters for all those new Teslas
What about if we started everything - reform, policy, coordination, programs etc - with: Will this help save lives?
Donors should consider a return to forms of budget support and other host government led approaches
Let us reimagine localisation and not make assumptions on what it is an isn’t
Disincentive earmarked funding by charging high overhead cost and favor flexible contributions
We need to de-center international aid. It is not the ‘sun’ of the international solar system. Communities are.
Responses would benefit from knowing where to find recent information about the event location before the crisis occurred. Someone knows
Comparative advantage whether human skills, access to funds/stocks or ability to deliver or engage should be used more.Too much duplication.
Too much of the humanitarian aid space is dominated by big orgs and the global north with no voices from the global majority
Review salaries within system. UN salaries currently ridiculously high for limited delivery, NGOs are significantly lower with higher risk
Focus should be on unified functional response system to save lives not a debate on local v international. Solidarity & collaboration is key
The rethink needs to be radical. We can’t tinker around the edges and expect things to improve. Now is the opportune time to make big change
Humanitarian aid should be short term & lifesaving. Too often we’re drawn into long term dev’t because host countries take no responsibility
Mind blowing amounts of wasted $ spent by NGOs & UN at HQ level on marketing & events to fundraise. Greater collab with pvt sector needed
The system needs to redefine roles of donors, international (NGO/UN) & local actors for responses. Blurred lines= duplication & inefficiency
UN needs to do some serious reform work. Starting with- defining roles, merging duplicate agencies, strengthning advocacy, reducing salaries
Host governments need to proactively lead, strategise, plan, fundraise & respond during crisis, & commit to work alongside internat’l actors
More focus on in-country experience. Many HQs are staffed almost entirely by out-of-touch staff who’ve only ever briefly visited a response
Better means of collecting & sharing data over long term for trend analysis. System data should be managed locally but available to all.
Aid worker safety is critical. A NotATarget soc media post is as ineffective as thoughts/prayers. Conflict actors & govts to be accountable.
Min standards for int’l orgs to even take part in a response. Too often underfunded, inexperienced junior staff doing more harm than good
Where is the local fundraising to go with the so-called local leadership? In-country wealthy and private sector should contribute more.
More junior internships with proper mentorship are needed across the board to build the capacity of all, whatever nationality they hold.
The abusive power structures and poor governance systems that wilfully create humanitarian disasters should not get direct aid funding!
Please can all the UN agencies go back to doing what they do best and stop duplicating the work of others (WFP!). Get rid of duplicated orgs
Remove endless working groups,task forces, steering committees...layers of bureaucracy that cost money, slow things down and achieve nothing
If you can't explain to me in one sentence what your programme is and why people need it, you shouldn't be doing it.
We need to be honest with ourselves; some aid is genuinely critical, lifesaving, and must be preserved. Others is not and should be cut.
Humanitarian principles are critical, even if they're personally challenging to apply. If we fail to defend them now, we'll regret it.
The sector has become too academic, cut-off from the realities on the ground, "innovating" and presenting "initiatives" that are useless
Adhering to humanitarian principles, especially neutrality is challenging and complex - but it's also vital. We dismiss them at our peril.
Get rid of regional offices for INGOs. They're the epitome of a bloated, bureaucratic system. What do the staff there do?!
Review UN R&R policies. Constantly rotating out of country is disruptive and inefficient. Noone needs 4 weeks R&R in Kyiv!!
